Issues.Title: angular upgrade to v14 deletes dist folder
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

13

### Description

ng build --configuration=prodfast
- Generating browser application bundles (phase: setup)...
An unhandled exception occurred: EBUSY: resource busy or locked, rmdir '/project/dist'

In my build case, it's being built in docker like:
docker run --env-file .env.prod -v "/export:/project/dist"

This way, the build is done in a clean enviroment, and the output of dist is mapped the the host enviroment and gets pushed to prod systems
But now it is attempting to do a rmdir of dist, and since that is a mount point and not a folder, it fails and builds no longer happen.


### Minimal Reproduction

build angular while the dist is actually a mountpoint instead of a folder

### Exception or Error

```text
An unhandled exception occurred: EBUSY: resource busy or locked, rmdir '/project/dist'
```


### Your Environment

```text
docker container inside bitbucket pipeline
```

Issues.Title: Angular CLI V15 + TS Target ES2022 - No longer tree shaking unused services correctly
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

Angular v14

### Description

Unused Services are not being tree-shaken correctly from the bundle output with

`"target": "es2022"` set in the `tsconfig.json` and Angular v15 installed.

This target is set by the Angular v15 migrations!

### Minimal Reproduction

I've created a repository.

1. Clone https://github.com/Coly010/ng-tree-shaking

## The Problem

With Angular V15, when`"target": "es2022` is set in `tsconfig.json`, `UnusedService` a service that is not used in the application, is not tree shaken from the bundle.

This can be reproduced by doing the following"

1. Checkout `angular-v15-es2022`
2. Run `npm install`
3. Run `npm run build`
4. Run `npm run check-tree-shaking`

You'll see a line output stating that `grep` managed to find the `UnusedService` in the bundle.

### This is a regression

To prove this is a regression, you can do the following:

1. Checkout `angular-v14-es2022`
2. Run `npm install`
3. Run `npm run build`
4. Run `npm run check-tree-shaking`

You'll not see a line output stating that `grep` managed to find the `UnusedService` in the bundle.

### Futhermore

If you set the `"target": "es2020` in `tsconfig.json` with Angular v15, the service is tree shaken correctly.

1. Checkout `angular-v15-es2020`
2. Run `npm install`
3. Run `npm run build`
4. Run `npm run check-tree-shaking`

You'll not see a line output stating that `grep` managed to find the `UnusedService` in the bundle.

Currently, import resolution within a Less stylesheet is limited to default Less behavior which does not include full node package resolution. Full resolution behavior will be added in a future change.

Issues.Body:
Currently you indirectly forces developer to only use a single huge Angular module. Instead of using multiple modules. Why?
Because every time you import a Material module, it increases the app size. And even more if you use a shared module for this.

Example: 

You import `MatButtonModule` in two modules. Use case: A page and a dialog with its own module. Build you app and you see duplicated code. The MatButton code is not reused. It appears two times in built code as exact copy.

There is also an article what descibes the use of shared modules: 
https://indepth.dev/posts/1191/stop-using-shared-material-module
This will reduce the app size. But does not fix the core issue. 

In this issue we want to find a solution. Find a way to import this Framework/Components only once and use it in every module in you app without increasing the app size for each module by Material modules. Maybe tree-shaking? Would forRoot/forChild work? I'm sure you have better ideas.

Issues.Title: bug(cdk/table): sticky cells not updated when filtering
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When using the CDK table together with a filter, the sticky style is not updated correctly.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3184240/216034061-fa057b56-41b5-4d92-86bb-bcb3406f0657.png)

I tried to fix this bug in the CDK, however I wasn't successful so far. Here are my findings:

1. The `CdkTable` calls the [updateStickyColumns()](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/cdk/table/sticky-styler.ts#L104) method of the `StickyStyler` correctly.
2. The `StickyStyler` adds the task to the `CoalescedStyleReducer` [here](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/cdk/table/sticky-styler.ts#L134).
3. In the `CoalescedStyleReducer` the last [this._getScheduleObservable()](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/cdk/table/coalesced-style-scheduler.ts#L75) event is not emitted until I trigger the next change detection cycle, e.g. by clicking on the table. The last state of [this._ngZone.isStable](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/cdk/table/coalesced-style-scheduler.ts#L97) is `false`.

Let me know if you have any ideas how to solve this.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open [Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-i94eq2?file=src%2Fapp%2Ftable-filtering-example.html).
2. Type `10` in the filter field.
3. Press backspace, so the filter results in `1` >> Some cells (3,4 and 7) are not sticky.
4. Trigger the next change detection cycle, e.g. by clicking on the table >> Sticky cells are displayed correct again.


### Expected Behavior

The sticky cells are updated when changing the filter value from `10` to `1`.

### Actual Behavior

Some cells (3, 4 and 7) do not have a sticky style.

### Environment

- Angular: 15.1.0
- CDK/Material: 15.1.0
- Browser(s): Chrome Version 109.0.5414.120
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows, Ubuntu
